I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia requested knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to support the preparation of a regional private sector 
development policy and capacity building of the rural-based private sector.1 The TA will assist the 
government in formulating an effective private sector development strategy for the eastern region 
of Mongolia in alignment with the objectives of the Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 
2030 and the Mongolia Regional Development Concept (MRDC).2 The TA will contribute to 
operational priorities 5 (promoting rural development and food security) and 6 (strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity) of ADB’s Strategy 2030.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Since  the  start  of  Mongolia’s transition to  a market  economy  in  1991,  income  and 
development disparities have emerged between the country’s urban and rural areas. For instance, 
at 34.9%, the rural poverty rate exceeds the national average (29.6%). Adequate infrastructure is 
virtually absent in rural areas, as evidenced by the 2018 Logistic Performance Index, which 
ranked  Mongolia  130th  out  of  160  economies.4 Not  surprisingly,  the  rural  private  sector’s 
contribution to the national economy is marginal except for a small number of large mines. This 
hampers employment and income-generation opportunities. As a consequence, the government 
has made rural development a priority, targeting the promotion of rural industrialization strategies, 
the development of value chains and activities, and fostering socioeconomic equality between 
urban and rural areas through the optimal utilization of the country’s abundant natural resources. 
 
3.  A sustainable regional development policy is required to boost the rural economy, and it 
needs to be underpinned by regional strategies for private sector development. Although the 
government approved the MRDC in 2001, the resulting achievements have not met expectations. 
Against this background, the Prime Minister’s Cabinet Secretariat and the National Development 
Agency (NDA) have been tasked with updating the MRDC and preparing policy and regulatory 
documents that reflect the current development needs. A critical part of the MRDC is to formulate 
the strategies needed to develop the private sector and to ensure that the scarce public resources 
are used to deliver the public goods that will drive forward sustainable private economic activity. 
Although the net migration rate of eastern Mongolia is the lowest among the regions outside the 
capital, Ulaanbaatar, special attention should be given to education and access to financial 
services at regional and provincial level to strengthen local labor market participants. 
 
4.  ADB supported the government’s efforts to design a regional development policy in 2015 
under a TA project that produced the first private sector development strategy in the country with 
a focus on the five aimags (provinces) of western Mongolia.5 As a follow-up to this previous 
support, the Cabinet Secretariat requested ADB to replicate the project in eastern Mongolia. This 
TA will focus on Dornod, Khentii, and Sukhbaatar aimags. Eastern Mongolia is heavily dependent 
on mining, animal husbandry, and services. However, despite its abundant natural endowment, it 
has not tapped the potential from its wealth of minerals, animals, fish, and crop farming. For 
                                                
1  The TA was requested by the Ministry of Finance during the country programming confirmation mission in November 
2018. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 16 May 2019. 
2  Government of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar; and Government of 
Mongolia. 2001. Mongolia Regional Development Concept. Ulaanbaatar. 
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
4  World Bank. 2018. Connecting to Complete: Trade Logistics in Global Economy. Washington, DC. 
5  ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Fostering Value-Added Activities in Western Mongolia. Manila.

2 
instance, despite accounting for about 18% of the country’s land area and more than 15% of its 
total livestock, the region only contributes 8% of overall agriculture production in Mongolia. 
Eastern Mongolia is bordered by the People’s Republic of China and the Russian Federation, the 
biggest economies in Northeast Asia. In this regard, tourism and animal product manufacturing 
can be further developed in the region. Moreover, the three eastern aimags are among the most 
underdeveloped,  sparsely  populated,  and  isolated  provinces  in  Mongolia,  with  an  alarming 
poverty rate of 43.9%. The TA will determine the priority sectors in the region’s economy, 
formulate a strategy to tap local resources, and promote information sharing and coordination 
between the aimags to achieve synergies and economies of scale. This will be supported by the 
preparation of a comprehensive private sector development policy for the region. The TA will also 
provide capacity-building support to ensure the successful implementation and sustainability of 
the regional strategy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: private sector participation in achieving the 
MRDC goals enhanced.6 The TA will have the following outcome: readiness for value-added 
activities that advance private sector development in the three eastern aimags enhanced.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Aimags’ economic competitiveness and potential assessed. The objective 
will be to define and assess the competitive and priority sectors for each aimag, as well as identify 
the key constraints that hinder local private sector development. This will complement the existing 
economic competitiveness index by providing a comprehensive analysis of the region’s economic 
sectors and priorities. The TA team will thus be able to pinpoint the economic potential of the 
region and can focus on formulating a private sector development strategy that meets the specific 
needs of eastern Mongolia. 
 
7.  Output 2: Eastern Mongolia’s private sector development strategy formulated. The 
TA team will design an action plan to develop the local economy in eastern Mongolia. The actions 
will include an assessment of the demand-and-supply situation in the three aimags and a 
production capacity survey. Moreover, the team will prepare economic projections for each aimag. 
The final deliverable will be a private sector development policy document for eastern Mongolia. 
 
8.  Output 3: Regional agribusiness cluster models designed. This output will focus on 
the design and planning of export-oriented regional agribusiness clusters. The TA team will 
identify opportunities to integrate micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises into international 
value chains, and design schemes for technology-enhanced business models and microfinance 
facilities to support the proposed clusters. The output will include (i) investment and market 
studies for selected private sector opportunities in priority sectors with a focus on value-added 
activities and exports; and (ii) training of public and private sector participants in the areas of 
agronomy, financial planning, supply chain management, and export documentation. 
 
9.  Output  4:  Coordination  and  information  sharing  for  economic  development 
between the three eastern aimags strengthened. The TA will support the establishment of 
                                                
6  Government of Mongolia. 2001. Mongolia Regional Development Concept. Ulaanbaatar. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
provincial  public–private  dialogue  councils  (PPDCs)  in  the  three  eastern  aimags,  and  a 
centralized (regional) PPDC to facilitate coordination between them. The PPDCs will help local 
governments to streamline their investment and private sector development operations and to 
optimize the use of their limited fiscal resources. Moreover, PPDCs will become a communication 
tool  to  deliver  the  messages  of  local  private  sector  participants  to  the  central  and  local 
governments. The TA will also support the development of a web-based online catalogue to 
promote information sharing and local private sector marketing. The catalogue will include micro, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises from Mongolia’s western and eastern regions, and may be 
replicated nationwide at a later stage. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $625,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF  6).  The  estimated  value  of  in-kind 
contributions from the Government of Mongolia is $25,000. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff 
remuneration, office accommodation, logistics and administrative support, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB  will  implement  the  TA from  1 July  2019  to  31  December  2021.  The  Cabinet 
Secretariat will be the executing agency and the local aimag governments of Dornod, Khentii, and 
Sukhbaatar will be the implementing agencies. ADB’s Mongolia Resident Mission will lead the TA 
under the One ADB approach by working closely with other ADB departments, including (i) the 
Department of Communications (regarding the conduct of workshops and training programs and 
the publication of knowledge products); and (ii) the Office of Information Systems and Technology 
(regarding the procurement of equipment, software, and other information technology needs).8 
 
12.  With support from the Cabinet Secretariat, the local aimag governments will form the 
regional PPDC, which will include representatives from local governments and the private sector, 
to guide the TA. The deputy head of the Cabinet Secretariat will lead the regional PPDC. The 
Cabinet Secretariat will present the proposed composition of the regional PPDC to ADB for no-
objection approval. The TA coordinator will be responsible for facilitating this PPDC. Strong 
emphasis will be placed on sustainably building the capacity of public and private sector personnel. 
To achieve this, government officials and representatives of local chambers of commerce will lead 
the design and implementation of key initiatives, while TA consultants play an active supporting 
role. Thus, the TA will provide an important learning-by-doing exercise that will (i) build internal 
capacity, (ii) strengthen the operational framework, and (iii) sustain the TA results. Domestic study 
tours will allow the three eastern aimags to gain and share valuable knowledge, and learn from 
ADB’s previous TA in western Mongolia (footnote 5). 
 
13.  TA support for conferences and workshops may include costs related to the venue, 
equipment rental, translations, printing and copying, meals, transportation, lodging, logistics and 
administrative support, and other expenditures with prior agreement from ADB. In line with 
standard ADB procedures, the TA will not support the executing agency’s management fees or 
related  costs  such  as  staff  salaries.  Other  executing  agency  resources,  such  as  office 
accommodation, will be provided as part of the government’s in-kind contribution. 
                                                
8  The project team will explore collaboration with Germany’s Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ), 
the Japan International Cooperation Agency, and other development partners.

4

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage eight consultants and one consulting firm to 
deliver the TA outputs. It will hire two international consultants, one as the project team leader, 
and six national consultants. Additionally, ADB will recruit a consulting firm through cost-quality 
selection. Given the required expertise, ADB will engage the consultants on an individual basis. 
Lump-sum payment contracts for consulting services will be considered where appropriate. ADB 
will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time 
to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.9 
 
16.  The consultants will be responsible for producing the TA outputs and deliverables in a 
timely and effective manner, and for organizing and carrying out all TA activities. Consultants will 
report to the ADB project officer. ADB will evaluate the progress of the TA during review missions 
and workshops, based on the performance targets and indicators defined in the design and 
monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
 
                                                
9  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
17.  ADB’s procurement. Through the TA, ADB will procure a small amount of equipment and 
software to support the delivery of the outputs. This may include office equipment, laptops, tablets, 
small servers, statistical software, and data and/or internet connections. ADB’s Mongolia Resident 
Mission will undertake the procurement in line with ADB’s Procurement Policy and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Unleashing the Private Sector to Drive Inclusive Growth in Eastern 
Mongolia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Aimags’ economic competitiveness and potential assessed 
1.1 Mobilize consultants by Q3 2019. 
1.2 Produce draft report by early Q4 2019. 
1.3 Produce final report by end Q4 2019. 
2.  Eastern Mongolia private sector development strategy formulated 
2.1 Complete research design and mobilize surveyors by Q1 2020. 
2.2 Complete regional demand-and-supply survey and production capacity survey as part of output 2 by Q4 
2020. 
2.3 Complete economic and social analysis of the data collected from the survey by Q4 2020. 
2.4 Produce the regional private sector development policy document by Q3 2021. 
3.  Regional agribusiness cluster models designed 
3.1 Produce a road map for agribusiness cluster models by Q3 2021. 
3.2 Complete investment and market studies by Q4 2020. 
3.3 Provide all training sessions by Q4 2021. 
4.  Coordination and information sharing for economic development between the three eastern 
aimags strengthened 
4.1 Create public–private dialogue councils in Sukhbaatar and Khentii aimags, and a centralized public–
private dialogue council by Q1 2020. 
4.2 Organize at least four regional conferences by Q4 2021. 
4.3 Develop online catalogue by Q3 2021.
